description: Evaluating arguments by identifying which statement most strengthens or weakens a given argument. Focus on evidence analysis and logical support.

concepts.name: Strengthening an Argument
concepts.description: Identifying evidence or statements that would make a conclusion more likely to be true
common_misconceptions: Choosing evidence that is merely relevant but doesn't strengthen
Selecting evidence that proves conclusion true rather than more likely
question_patterns: Which statement most strengthens the argument that [conclusion]?
What evidence would best support the claim?
example_stems: The park should be expanded because it will improve air quality. Which finding would strengthen this argument?
Scientists claim the medicine is effective. What would best support this?

concepts.name: Weakening an Argument
concepts.description: Identifying evidence or statements that would make a conclusion less likely to be true
common_misconceptions: Confusing attacking the person with attacking the argument
Choosing information that is irrelevant to the conclusion
question_patterns: Which statement most weakens the argument?
What would cast doubt on this conclusion?
example_stems: The new highway will reduce traffic. What finding would weaken this claim?
Early bedtimes improve grades. Which discovery would challenge this?

concepts.name: Identifying Underlying Assumptions
concepts.description: Finding unstated beliefs that must be true for an argument to be valid
question_patterns: What assumption does this argument rely on?
What must be true for this conclusion to follow?
example_stems: The candidate has experience, so they'll be effective. What assumption is made?
Reading improves vocabulary, so students should read more. What is assumed?

concepts.name: Evaluating Quality of Evidence
concepts.description: Assessing whether evidence is relevant, reliable, and sufficient to support a claim
common_misconceptions: Accepting any evidence as equally valuable
Not considering sample size or bias
question_patterns: Which evidence best supports the conclusion?
What is the strongest piece of evidence for [claim]?
example_stems: Which study design would best test the claim?
What evidence would most convincingly prove the theory?

concepts.name: Identifying Logical Flaws
concepts.description: Recognizing errors in reasoning such as false cause, hasty generalization, or circular reasoning
common_misconceptions: Confusing weak arguments with flawed arguments
Missing the specific flaw in reasoning
question_patterns: What is the flaw in this reasoning?
example_stems: After the new CEO started, profits rose. The CEO must have improved profits. What's the flaw?
Most successful people wake up early. To succeed, wake up early. What's wrong with this reasoning?

concepts.name: Constructing Counter-Arguments
concepts.description: Developing alternative explanations or objections that challenge a given argument
common_misconceptions: Simply denying the conclusion without providing reasoning
question_patterns: What is the best counter-argument to this claim?
How might someone challenge this conclusion?
example_stems: The program reduced crime, so it should continue. What's the best objection?
Homework improves learning. What would challenge this?
